original_data.question: A 3rd year resident in good standing with his residency training program would like to work more hours outside his residency obligations to gain more experience and pay for his medical school loans. He currently works and trains 60 hours per week as a resident and has a 10-hour shift external to his residency program on Saturdays. He is free of any educational and work obligations on Sundays. Based on the most recent standards set by the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education (ACGME), which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding this resident’s moonlighting and patient safety?

options.A: He is already overcommitting and must reduce the number of hours
options.B: He is not allowed to work outside the scope of his residency training
options.D: He may work up to 20 more hours

model_response: {'A': False, as he is already working 60 hours per week as a resident, so adding 10 hours of moonlighting is not overcommitting. Moonlighting hours must not be counted towards the 80-hour maximum hours per week limit.', 'B': False, as the ACGME does not prohibit residents from working outside the scope of their residency training. However, the institution where the resident is training must ensure that the education provided is the primary focus.', 'C': False, as the ACGME has not set any specific limit on shift length. However, shift length must be within the 80-hour per week limit.', 'D': True, as the ACGME allows a maximum of 10 hours per week of moonlighting, which must be in addition to the 80-hour per week limit for resident work hours. Moonlighting hours must not be counted towards the 80-hour maximum hours per week limit.}</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A physician who has completed medical school and an internship and is in the process of receiving specialised training.
Valuable or useful or agreeable or pleasing.
The act of assuming or maintaining an erect upright position.
Duties that are based in ETHICS, rather than in law.
Educational institutions for individuals specializing in the field of medicine.

A collective term for muscle and ligament injuries without dislocation or fracture. A sprain is a joint injury in which some of the fibers of a supporting ligament are ruptured but the continuity of the ligament remains intact. A strain is an overstretching or overexertion of some part of the musculature.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
A physician who has completed medical school and an internship and is in the process of receiving specialised training.
The seventh and last day of the week.
EDUCATION that prepares the student for a specific trade such as plumbing, masonry, and carpentry.
Duties that are based in ETHICS, rather than in law.
The first day of the week.

question_entities.text: Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education
question_entities.definition: Educational programs for medical graduates entering a specialty. They include formal specialty training as well as academic work in the clinical and basic medical sciences, and may lead to board certification or an advanced medical degree.
The quality of nearness to the truth or the true value.
A verbal and/or written message that asserts, affirms, or declares something.
A physician who has completed medical school and an internship and is in the process of receiving specialised training.
Efforts to reduce risk, to address and reduce incidents and accidents that may negatively impact healthcare consumers.
